pullRequest.body:
In this PR we prove that a non-archimedean non-trivial absolute value on the rational is equivalent to a padic one.

Main result
```lean
theorem mulRingNorm_equiv_padic_of_bounded :
    ∃! p, ∃ (hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)), MulRingNorm.equiv f (mulRingNorm_padic p)
```

Co-authored-by:

David Kurniadi Angdinata [dka31@cantab.ac.uk](mailto:dka31@cantab.ac.uk)
Laura Capuano [laura.capuano@uniroma3.it](mailto:laura.capuano@uniroma3.it)
Nirvana Coppola [nirvanac93@gmail.com](mailto:nirvanac93@gmail.com)
María Inés de Frutos Fernández [maria.defrutos@uam.es](mailto:maria.defrutos@uam.es)
Sam van Gool [vangool@irif.fr](mailto:vangool@irif.fr)
Silvain Rideau-Kikuchi [silvain.rideau-kikuchi@ens.fr](mailto:silvain.rideau-kikuchi@ens.fr)
Amos Turchet [amos.turchet@uniroma3.it](mailto:amos.turchet@uniroma3.it)
Francesco Veneziano [veneziano@dima.unige.it](mailto:veneziano@dima.unige.it)

---

@fbarroero Can you change "Nat" to "nat" in `eq_on_Nat_iff_eq_on_Int` and the following two lemmas in a follow-up PR? Also, there should be spaces around `^` in
```lean
lemma equiv_on_Nat_iff_equiv : (∃ c : ℝ, 0 < c ∧ (∀ n : ℕ , (f n)^c = g n)) ↔ f.equiv g
```
But this is, I think, out of scope for this PR.

> @fbarroero Can you change "Nat" to "nat" in `eq_on_Nat_iff_eq_on_Int` and the following two lemmas in a follow-up PR? Also, there should be spaces around `^` in
> 
> ```lean
> lemma equiv_on_Nat_iff_equiv : (∃ c : ℝ, 0 < c ∧ (∀ n : ℕ , (f n)^c = g n)) ↔ f.equiv g
> ```
> 
> But this is, I think, out of scope for this PR.

Why should I not do it in this PR?

> Why should I not do it in this PR?

You can of course do that here, too, if you like. I just didn't want to make that a requirement, as it is somewhat orthogonal to the original purpose.

Thanks!

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9660348640/job/26645728460)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9660348640/job/26645728730)
LGTM!
It should not be necessary to name the instance argument (which can be written a bit shorter as `Fact p.Prime`, but this is a matter of taste).

```suggestion
lemma exists_minimal_nat_zero_lt_mulRingNorm_lt_one : ∃ p : ℕ, (0 < f p ∧ f p < 1) ∧
    ∀ m : ℕ, 0 < f m ∧ f m < 1 → p ≤ m := by
```
"smallest" is not used much in Mathlib names, and `nat` should be lower case according to [naming convention](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html) no. 5.

```suggestion
  have hn : ∃ n : ℕ, n ≠ 0 ∧ f n ≠ 1 := by
```

```suggestion
/-- There exists a minimal positive integer with absolute value smaller than 1. -/
```
See "Doc strings" in the [documentation guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html).

```suggestion
  neg'      := by simp only [padicNorm.neg, forall_const]
```

```suggestion
    contrapose! hf_nontriv
    rw [← eq_on_Nat_iff_eq]
    intro n
    rcases eq_or_ne n 0 with rfl | hn0
    · simp only [Nat.cast_zero, map_zero]
    · simp only [MulRingNorm.apply_one, Nat.cast_eq_zero, hn0, ↓reduceIte, hf_nontriv n hn0]
```
`contrapose! hf_nontriv` does the equivalent of `by_contra! h; apply hf_nontriv` (but the hypothesis will have a different name). Instead of `apply`ing one direction of an equivalence, one can rewrite.

You can do this while stating and proving `hn`:
```lean
  obtain ⟨n, hn1, hn2⟩ : ∃ n : ℕ, n ≠ 0 ∧ f n ≠ 1 := by
```

```suggestion
  have hP : P.Nonempty :=
    ⟨n, map_pos_of_ne_zero f (Nat.cast_ne_zero.mpr hn1), lt_of_le_of_ne (bdd n) hn2⟩
  exact ⟨sInf P, Nat.sInf_mem hP, fun m hm ↦ Nat.sInf_le hm⟩
```
`use`, followed by `exact` can usually be combined into a single `exact` (and `by exact` cancels in most cases).
This is not necessary, as it can be proved by `omega` (see below).

```suggestion
variable (p : ℕ) (hp0 : 0 < f p) (hp1 : f p < 1) (hmin : ∀ m : ℕ, 0 < f m ∧ f m < 1 → p ≤ m)
```

```suggestion
lemma is_prime_of_smallest_Nat_zero_lt_mulRingNorm_lt_one : p.Prime := by
```
Going via the generic `Prime` predicate seems to be a detour. (This requires a few changes downstream, but they are mostly simplifying the proofs.)

```suggestion
  · rw [Nat.isUnit_iff]
    rintro rfl
    simp only [Nat.cast_one, map_one, lt_self_iff_false] at hp1
  · rintro a b rfl
    rw [Nat.isUnit_iff, Nat.isUnit_iff]
    by_contra! con
    obtain ⟨ha₁, hb₁⟩ := con
    obtain ⟨ha₀, hb₀⟩ : a ≠ 0 ∧ b ≠ 0 := by
      refine mul_ne_zero_iff.1 fun H ↦ ?_
      rwa [H, Nat.cast_zero, map_zero, lt_self_iff_false] at hp0
    have hap : a < a * b := lt_mul_of_one_lt_right (by omega) (by omega)
    have hbp : b < a * b := lt_mul_of_one_lt_left (by omega) (by omega)
    have Ha := le_of_not_lt <| not_and.1 ((hmin a).mt hap.not_le) (map_pos_of_ne_zero _ (mod_cast ha₀))
    have Hb := le_of_not_lt <| not_and.1 ((hmin b).mt hbp.not_le) (map_pos_of_ne_zero _ (mod_cast hb₀))
    rw [Nat.cast_mul, map_mul] at hp1
    exact ((one_le_mul_of_one_le_of_one_le Ha Hb).trans_lt hp1).false
```
Note the `rintro rfl` trick, which does a substitution at the same time as the introduction.

```suggestion
/-- A natural number not divible by p has absolute value 1. -/
```

```suggestion
lemma mulRingNorm_eq_one_of_not_dvd {m : ℕ} (hpm : ¬ p ∣ m) : f m = 1 := by
```
`m` can be implicit, as it can be deduced from `hpm`. (Then when the lemma is used, the corresponding argument needs to be left out.)
`1/2` should be `1 / 2` (with spaces) everywhere,

```suggestion
  obtain ⟨a, b, bezout⟩ : IsCoprime (p ^ k : ℤ) (m ^ k) := by
    apply IsCoprime.pow (Nat.Coprime.isCoprime _)
    exact (Nat.Prime.coprime_iff_not_dvd
      (is_prime_of_smallest_Nat_zero_lt_mulRingNorm_lt_one p hp0 hp1 hmin)).2 hpm
```

```suggestion
  have le_half {x} (hx0 : 0 < x) (hx1 : x < 1) (hxM : x ≤ M) : x ^ k < 1 / 2 := by
```

```suggestion
    x ^ k = x ^ (k : ℝ) := (rpow_natCast x k).symm
```

```suggestion
    _ < x ^ M.logb (1 / 2) := by
```

```suggestion
    _ ≤ x ^ x.logb (1 / 2) := by
```

```suggestion
      simp only [one_div, ← log_div_log, log_inv, neg_div, ← div_neg, hM]
```
(obtained from `simp? only [...]`)

```suggestion
      exact log_neg (lt_sup_iff.2 <| Or.inl hp0) (sup_lt_iff.2 ⟨hp1, hm⟩)
```

```suggestion
  1 = f 1 := (map_one f).symm
```

```suggestion
    have hm₀ : 0 < f m :=
      map_pos_of_ne_zero _ <| Nat.cast_ne_zero.2 fun H ↦ hpm <| H ▸ dvd_zero p
    linarith only [le_half hp0 hp1 le_sup_left, le_half hm₀ hm le_sup_right]
```

```suggestion
lemma exists_pos_mulRingNorm_eq_pow_neg : ∃ t : ℝ, 0 < t ∧ f p = p ^ (-t) := by
  have pprime := is_prime_of_smallest_Nat_zero_lt_mulRingNorm_lt_one p hp0 hp1 hmin
  refine ⟨- logb p (f p), Left.neg_pos_iff.2 <| logb_neg (mod_cast pprime.one_lt) hp0 hp1, ?_⟩
  rw [neg_neg]
  refine (rpow_logb (mod_cast pprime.pos) ?_ hp0).symm
  simp only [ne_eq, Nat.cast_eq_one,Nat.Prime.ne_one pprime, not_false_eq_true]
```

```suggestion
  have hprime := is_prime_of_smallest_Nat_zero_lt_mulRingNorm_lt_one p hfp.1 hfp.2 hmin
  have hprime_fact : Fact (Nat.Prime p) := ⟨hprime⟩
  use p, hprime_fact
```

```suggestion
  refine ⟨t⁻¹, by simp only [inv_pos, h.1], fun n ↦ ?_⟩
  have ht : t⁻¹ ≠ 0 := inv_ne_zero h.1.ne
```

```suggestion
  rcases eq_or_ne n 0 with rfl | hn -- Separate cases n=0 and n ≠ 0
  · simp only [Nat.cast_zero, map_zero, ne_eq, ht, not_false_eq_true, zero_rpow]
  · /- Any natural number can be written as a power of p times a natural number not divisible
    by p  -/
    rcases Nat.exists_eq_pow_mul_and_not_dvd hn p hprime.ne_one with ⟨e, m, hpm, rfl⟩
    simp only [Nat.cast_mul, Nat.cast_pow, map_mul, map_pow, mulRingNorm_eq_padic_norm,
      padicNorm.padicNorm_p_of_prime, Rat.cast_inv, Rat.cast_natCast, inv_pow,
      mulRingNorm_eq_one_of_not_dvd bdd p hfp.1 hfp.2 hmin hpm, h.2]
    rw [← padicNorm.nat_eq_one_iff] at hpm
    simp only [← rpow_natCast, p.cast_nonneg, ← rpow_mul, mul_one, ← rpow_neg, hpm, cast_one]
    congr
    field_simp [h.1.ne']
    ring
```
These computations with real (or complex) powers could use a bit more automation...
I've tried to reduce to an equality of exponents that can be dealt with using `field_simp; ring`.
Thanks! I didn't know about `field_simp`...

```suggestion
variable {p : ℕ} (hp0 : 0 < f p) (hp1 : f p < 1) (hmin : ∀ m : ℕ, 0 < f m ∧ f m < 1 → p ≤ m)
```
This line is useless (`f` is already declared, you may want to move the comment).
`p` is unique, right? Is it hard to prove it?
That should be quite easy (using that `f(q) = 1` for other primes).
I am going to add that! Thanks
I added the uniqueness of p, thanks for having suggested it

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - Feat (NumberTheory/Ostrowski): Proof of the non-archimedean case of Ostrowski's Theorem
